pcg_stein.distribution module¶

class pcg_stein.distribution.BayesianLogisticRegression(X, y, sigma_prior=10.0)¶

Bases: Distribution

Bayesian logistic regression with Gaussian prior and MH sampler.

Use from_synthetic() to build a model instance directly from a true parameter vector – handy for demos, teaching, or simulation studies.

Parameters:

  • X (Array)

  • y (Array)

  • sigma_prior (float | Array)

__init__(X, y, sigma_prior=10.0)¶
Parameters:

  • X (Array)

  • y (Array)

  • sigma_prior (float | Array)

static _log_sigmoid(x)¶

Numerically stable log(sigmoid(x)).

x (Array)

classmethod from_synthetic(key, n_samples, true_beta, *, add_intercept=True, X=None, sigma_prior=10.0)¶

Generate synthetic (X, y) from a known coefficient vector.

Parameters:

  • key (Array) – JAX PRNG key.

  • n_samples (int) – Number of rows to simulate.

  • true_beta (Array) – 1D array of shape (d,). If add_intercept=True, element 0 is the intercept; otherwise all elements are slopes.

  • add_intercept (bool, optional) – Whether to prepend a column of ones to X so that its number of columns equals len(true_beta). Defaults to True.

  • X (optional) – Design matrix to reuse. See shape rules below.

  • sigma_prior (float or Array) – Prior scale(s) for generating synthetic noise.

Returns:

Tuple (X, y) where X is the design matrix and y is the response vector.

Return type:

Tuple[Array, Array]

Shape rules:

-If add_intercept=True:

  • If X is None, a random matrix of shape (n, d - 1) is drawn and a ones column is prepended.

  • If X is provided, it may:

    • Have shape (n, d - 1) → a ones column is prepended.

    • Have shape (n, d) → it is used as-is, with its own intercept.

-If add_intercept=False:

  • X must already have d columns (matching len(true_beta)).

sample(key, num_samples, *, step_size=0.1, burn_in=1000, thinning=1, init_beta=None, unique=True)¶

Draws num_samples posterior samples (after burn‑in & thinning).

Parameters:

  • key (Array) – Array PRNG key.

  • num_samples (int) – int Number of stored samples returned.

  • step_size (float) – float, default 0.1 Std. dev. of random‑walk proposal.

  • burn_in (int) – int, default 1000 Number of warm‑up iterations (discarded).

  • thinning (int) – int, default 1 Keep every thinning‑th draw after burn‑in.

  • init_beta (Optional[Array]) – Array | None Initial parameter vector. If None, starts at 0.

  • unique (bool) – bool, default True Compile core MH step with jax.jit (worthwhile for long chains).

Return type:

Array

Returns:

JAX array of MH samples.

pcg_stein.kernel module¶

class pcg_stein.kernel.GaussianKernel¶

Bases: Kernel

static _phi(r, *, lengthscale=1.0, amplitude=1.0)¶

Computes the radial profile \(\varphi(r)\) of the Gaussian (RBF) kernel.

This defines the scalar-valued kernel as a function of the Euclidean distance \(r = \lVert x - y \rVert\), with the following form:

\[\varphi(r) = \sigma^2 \exp\left(-\frac{r^2}{2 \ell^2}\right),\]

where \(\sigma^2\) is the amplitude and \(\ell\) is the lengthscale.

Parameters:

  • r (Array) – Euclidean distance of shape (1,). Must represent a single scalar value.

  • lengthscale (float, optional) – Lengthscale parameter \(\ell>0\). Defaults to 1.0.

  • amplitude (float, optional) – Amplitude parameter \(\sigma^2>0\). Defaults to 1.0.

Returns:

The scalar kernel value \(\varphi(r)\) evaluated at the given distance.

Return type:

Array

static _phi_pp(r, *, lengthscale=1.0, amplitude=1.0)¶

Computes the second derivative of the Gaussian (RBF) radial profile with respect to the distance \(r\), i.e. \(\varphi''(r)\).

This quantity appears in Stein kernel constructions involving second-order terms.

\[\varphi''(r) = \frac{\sigma^2}{\ell^2} \left( \frac{r^2}{\ell^2} - 1 \right) \exp\left(-\frac{r^2}{2 \ell^2}\right),\]

where \(\sigma^2\) is the amplitude and \(\ell\) is the lengthscale.

Parameters:

  • r (Array) – Euclidean distance of shape (1,). Must represent a single scalar value.

  • lengthscale (float, optional) – Lengthscale parameter \(\ell>0\). Defaults to 1.0.

  • amplitude (float, optional) – Amplitude parameter \(\sigma^2>0\). Defaults to 1.0.

Returns:

The scalar value \(\varphi''(r)\) evaluated at the given distance.

Return type:

Array

static _psi(r, *, lengthscale=1.0, amplitude=1.0)¶

Computes the first derivative of the Gaussian (RBF) radial profile divided by \(r\), i.e. \(\psi(r) = \varphi'(r) / r\).

This quantity is finite at \(r = 0\) and is used in Stein kernel computations.

\[\psi(r) = -\frac{\sigma^2}{\ell^2} \exp\left(-\frac{r^2}{2 \ell^2}\right),\]

where \(\sigma^2\) is the amplitude and \(\ell\) is the lengthscale.

Parameters:

  • r (Array) – Euclidean distance of shape (1,). Must represent a single scalar value.

  • lengthscale (float, optional) – Lengthscale parameter \(\ell>0\). Defaults to 1.0.

  • amplitude (float, optional) – Amplitude parameter \(\sigma^2>0\). Defaults to 1.0.

Returns:

The scalar value \(\psi(r) = \varphi'(r) / r\) evaluated at the given distance.

Return type:

Array

class pcg_stein.kernel.IMQKernel¶

Bases: Kernel

static _phi(r, *, lengthscale=1.0, amplitude=1.0, gamma=1.0, beta=0.5)¶

Computes the radial profile \(\varphi(r)\) of the Inverse Multiquadric (IMQ) kernel.

This defines a scalar-valued kernel as a function of the Euclidean distance \(r = \lVert x - y \rVert\), using the form:

\[\varphi(r) = \sigma^{2} \, u(r)^{-\beta}, \quad u(r) = \gamma^{2} + \frac{r^{2}}{\ell^{2}},\]

where \(\sigma^{2}\) is the amplitude, \(\ell\) is the lengthscale, and \(\gamma\), \(\beta\) are additional hyperparameters.

Parameters:

  • r (Array) – Euclidean distance of shape (1,). Must represent a single scalar value.

  • lengthscale (float, optional) – Lengthscale parameter \(\ell > 0\). Defaults to 1.0.

  • amplitude (float, optional) – Amplitude parameter \(\sigma^{2} > 0\). Defaults to 1.0.

  • gamma (float, optional) – Offset parameter \(\gamma > 0\). Controls the flatness of the kernel. Defaults to 1.0.

  • beta (float, optional) – Exponent parameter \(\beta \in (0, 1)\). Controls the decay rate. Defaults to 0.5.

Returns:

The scalar kernel value \(\varphi(r)\) evaluated at the given distance.

Return type:

Array

static _phi_pp(r, *, lengthscale=1.0, amplitude=1.0, gamma=1.0, beta=0.5)¶

Computes the second derivative of the Inverse Multiquadric (IMQ) radial profile with respect to the distance \(r\), i.e. \(\varphi''(r)\).

This quantity is used in Stein kernel constructions involving second-order terms.

The IMQ kernel is defined in terms of the squared offset function \(u(r) = \gamma^2 + r^2 / \ell^2\):

\[\varphi''(r) = \sigma^{2} \, u(r)^{-(\beta + 2)} \left[ -\frac{2\beta}{\ell^{2}} u(r) + \frac{4\beta(\beta + 1) r^{2}}{\ell^{4}} \right], \quad u(r) = \gamma^{2} + \frac{r^{2}}{\ell^{2}},\]

where \(\sigma^{2}\) is the amplitude, \(\ell\) is the lengthscale, and \(\gamma\), \(\beta\) are additional hyperparameters.

Parameters:

  • r (Array) – Euclidean distance of shape (1,). Must represent a single scalar value.

  • lengthscale (float, optional) – Lengthscale parameter \(\ell > 0\). Defaults to 1.0.

  • amplitude (float, optional) – Amplitude parameter \(\sigma^{2} > 0\). Defaults to 1.0.

  • gamma (float, optional) – Offset parameter \(\gamma > 0\). Controls the flatness of the kernel. Defaults to 1.0.

  • beta (float, optional) – Exponent parameter \(\beta \in (0, 1)\). Controls the decay rate. Defaults to 0.5.

Returns:

The scalar value \(\varphi''(r)\) evaluated at the given distance.

Return type:

Array

static _psi(r, *, lengthscale=1.0, amplitude=1.0, gamma=1.0, beta=0.5)¶

Computes the first derivative of the Inverse Multiquadric (IMQ) radial profile divided by \(r\), i.e. \(\psi(r) = \varphi'(r) / r\).

This quantity is finite at \(r = 0\) and is used in Stein kernel computations.

The IMQ kernel is defined as a function of the Euclidean distance \(r = \lVert x - y \rVert\) by:

\[\psi(r) = -\frac{2 \beta \sigma^{2}}{\ell^{2}} \, u(r)^{-(\beta + 1)}, \quad u(r) = \gamma^{2} + \frac{r^{2}}{\ell^{2}},\]

where \(\sigma^{2}\) is the amplitude, \(\ell\) is the lengthscale, and \(\gamma\), \(\beta\) are additional hyperparameters.

Parameters:

  • r (Array) – Euclidean distance of shape (1,). Must represent a single scalar value.

  • lengthscale (float, optional) – Lengthscale parameter \(\ell > 0\). Defaults to 1.0.

  • amplitude (float, optional) – Amplitude parameter \(\sigma^{2} > 0\). Defaults to 1.0.

  • gamma (float, optional) – Offset parameter \(\gamma > 0\). Controls the flatness of the kernel. Defaults to 1.0.

  • beta (float, optional) – Exponent parameter \(\beta \in (0, 1)\). Controls the decay rate. Defaults to 0.5.

Returns:

The scalar value \(\psi(r) = \varphi'(r) / r\) evaluated at the given distance.

Return type:

Array

class pcg_stein.kernel.Kernel¶

Bases: object

__call__(X, Y=None, **hyper)¶

Evaluates the base kernel or its Gram matrix.

If Y is not provided, computes the Gram matrix K(X, X) between all pairs in X. If Y is provided, computes the cross Gram matrix K(X, Y).

Parameters:

  • X (Array) – An (n × d) array of input samples.

  • Y (Optional[Array], optional) – An (m × d) array of input samples. If None, defaults to X. Defaults to None.

  • **hyper (Any) – Additional kernel hyperparameters.

Returns:

The (n × m) Gram matrix of base kernel evaluations, or a scalar if both X and Y are single points.

Return type:

Array

_pair(x, y, **hyper)¶

Evaluates the base kernel function between two samples.

Parameters:

  • x (Array) – A single sample of shape (d,).

  • y (Array) – A single sample of shape (d,).

  • **hyper (Any) – Additional kernel hyperparameters.

Returns:

A scalar representing the kernel evaluation between x and y.

Return type:

Array

static _phi(r, **hyper)¶
static _phi_pp(r, **hyper)¶
static _psi(r, **hyper)¶
_stein_pair(x, y, s_x, s_y, **hyper)¶

Computes the pairwise Stein kernel entry between two points.

Parameters:

  • x (Array) – A single sample of shape (d,).

  • y (Array) – A single sample of shape (d,).

  • s_x (Array) – Score function evaluated at x of shape (d,).

  • s_y (Array) – Score function evaluated at y of shape (d,).

  • **hyper (Any) – Additional kernel hyperparameters.

Returns:

A scalar representing the Stein kernel between x and y.

Return type:

Array

stein_matrix(X, Y, Sx, Sy, **hyper)¶

Computes the Stein kernel Gram matrix between two sets of samples.

This returns an (n × m) block matrix, where each entry corresponds to a Stein kernel evaluation between points from X and Y with associated scores Sx and Sy, using the given kernel and hyperparameters.

Parameters:

  • X (Array) – An (n × d) array of samples.

  • Y (Array) – An (m × d) array of samples.

  • Sx (Array) – An (n × d) array of score function evaluations for X.

  • Sy (Array) – An (m × d) array of score function evaluations for Y.

  • **hyper (Any) – Additional kernel hyperparameters.

Returns:

An (n × m) Gram matrix of Stein kernel evaluations.

Return type:

Array

class pcg_stein.kernel.Matern52Kernel¶

Bases: Kernel

static _phi(r, *, lengthscale=1.0, amplitude=1.0)¶

The radial profile \(\varphi(r)\) of the Matérn 5/2 kernel (smoothness parameter \(\nu = 5/2\)).

This defines the scalar-valued kernel as a function of the Euclidean distance \(r = \lVert x - y \rVert\), with the following form:

\[\varphi(r) = \sigma^{2} \left( 1 + c r + \tfrac{c^{2}}{3} r^{2} \right) e^{-c r}, \quad c = \frac{\sqrt{5}}{\ell},\]

where \(\sigma^2\) is the amplitude and \(\ell\) is the lengthscale.

Parameters:

  • r (Array) – Pairwise Euclidean distance of shape (1,).

  • lengthscale (float, optional) – Lengthscale parameter \(\ell>0\). Defaults to 1.0.

  • amplitude (float, optional) – Amplitude parameter \(\sigma^2>0\). Defaults to 1.0.

Returns:

The kernel value \(\varphi(r)\) evaluated at the given distance.

Return type:

Array

static _phi_pp(r, *, lengthscale=1.0, amplitude=1.0)¶

Computes the second derivative of the Matérn 5/2 radial profile with respect to the distance \(r\), i.e. \(\varphi''(r)\).

This quantity appears in Stein kernel constructions involving second-order terms.

\[\varphi''(r) = -\,\sigma^{2} \frac{c^{2}}{3} \left(1 + c r - c^{2} r^{2} \right) e^{-c r}, \quad c = \frac{\sqrt{5}}{\ell},\]

where \(\sigma^{2}\) is the amplitude and \(\ell\) is the lengthscale.

Parameters:

  • r (Array) – Euclidean distance of shape (1,). Must represent a single scalar value.

  • lengthscale (float, optional) – Lengthscale parameter \(\ell>0\). Defaults to 1.0.

  • amplitude (float, optional) – Amplitude parameter \(\sigma^2>0\). Defaults to 1.0.

Returns:

The scalar value \(\varphi''(r)\) evaluated at the given distance.

Return type:

Array

static _psi(r, *, lengthscale=1.0, amplitude=1.0)¶

Computes the first derivative of the Matérn 5/2 radial profile divided by \(r\), i.e. \(\psi(r) = \varphi'(r)/r\).

This quantity is finite at \(r = 0\) and is used in Stein kernel computations.

\[\psi(r) = -\,\sigma^{2} \frac{c^{2}}{3} (1 + c r) e^{-c r}, \quad c = \frac{\sqrt{5}}{\ell},\]

where \(\sigma^{2}\) is the amplitude and \(\ell\) is the lengthscale.

Parameters:

  • r (Array) – Euclidean distance of shape (1,). Must represent a single scalar value.

  • lengthscale (float, optional) – Lengthscale parameter \(\ell>0\). Defaults to 1.0.

  • amplitude (float, optional) – Amplitude parameter \(\sigma^2>0\). Defaults to 1.0.

Returns:

The scalar value \(\psi(r) = \varphi'(r) / r\) evaluated at the given distance.

Return type:

Array

class pcg_stein.kernel.Matern72Kernel¶

Bases: Kernel

static _phi(r, *, lengthscale=1.0, amplitude=1.0)¶

Computes the radial profile \(\varphi(r)\) of the Matérn kernel with smoothness parameter \(\nu = 7/2\).

This defines the scalar-valued kernel as a function of the Euclidean distance \(r = \lVert x - y \rVert\), with the following form:

\[\varphi(r) = \sigma^{2} \left( 1 + c r + \tfrac{c^{2}}{3} r^{2} + \tfrac{c^{3}}{15} r^{3} \right) e^{-c r}, \quad c = \frac{\sqrt{7}}{\ell},\]

where \(\sigma^2\) is the amplitude and \(\ell\) is the lengthscale.

Parameters:

  • r (Array) – Euclidean distance of shape (1,). Must represent a single scalar value.

  • lengthscale (float, optional) – Lengthscale parameter \(\ell>0\). Defaults to 1.0.

  • amplitude (float, optional) – Amplitude parameter \(\sigma^2>0\). Defaults to 1.0.

Returns:

The scalar kernel value \(\varphi(r)\) evaluated at the given distance.

Return type:

Array

static _phi_pp(r, *, lengthscale=1.0, amplitude=1.0)¶

Computes the second derivative of the Matérn 7/2 radial profile with respect to the distance \(r\), i.e. \(\varphi''(r)\).

This quantity appears in Stein kernel constructions involving second-order terms.

\[\varphi''(r) = \frac{\sigma^{2} c^{2}}{15} \left( -5 + c r - c^{2} r^{2} + c^{3} r^{3} \right) e^{-c r}, \quad c = \frac{\sqrt{7}}{\ell},\]

where \(\sigma^{2}\) is the amplitude and \(\ell\) is the lengthscale.

Parameters:

  • r (Array) – Euclidean distance of shape (1,). Must represent a single scalar value.

  • lengthscale (float, optional) – Lengthscale parameter \(\ell>0\). Defaults to 1.0.

  • amplitude (float, optional) – Amplitude parameter \(\sigma^2>0\). Defaults to 1.0.

Returns:

The scalar value \(\varphi''(r)\) evaluated at the given distance.

Return type:

Array

static _psi(r, *, lengthscale=1.0, amplitude=1.0)¶

Computes the first derivative of the Matérn 7/2 radial profile divided by \(r\), i.e. \(\psi(r) = \varphi'(r) / r\).

This quantity is finite at \(r = 0\) and is used in Stein kernel computations.

\[\psi(r) = \frac{\sigma^{2} c^{2}}{15} \left( 5 + 2 c r + c^{2} r^{2} \right) e^{-c r}, \quad c = \frac{\sqrt{7}}{\ell},\]

where \(\sigma^{2}\) is the amplitude and \(\ell\) is the lengthscale.

Parameters:

  • r (Array) – Euclidean distance of shape (1,). Must represent a single scalar value.

  • lengthscale (float, optional) – Lengthscale parameter \(\ell>0\). Defaults to 1.0.

  • amplitude (float, optional) – Amplitude parameter \(\sigma^2>0\). Defaults to 1.0.

Returns:

The scalar value \(\psi(r) = \varphi'(r) / r\) evaluated at the given distance.

Return type:

Array

pcg_stein.pcg module¶

pcg_stein.pcg._pcg_core(A, b, *, rtol=1e-06, atol=1e-06, wce_tol=0.0, maxiter=1000, M_inv=None, x0=None)¶

Core implementation of the Preconditioned Conjugate Gradient (PCG) method for solving the linear system \(Ax = b\).

This internal function is JIT-compiled for performance and supports optional left preconditioning using a symmetric positive definite matrix \(M^{-1}\). It also tracks the worst-case error (WCE), which provides a computable upper bound on the error of kernel-based integration estimates.

Parameters:

  • A – Linear operator or matrix representing \(A\). Must be symmetric positive semi-definite and support A @ x.

  • b (Array) – Right-hand side vector.

  • rtol (float, optional) – Relative tolerance for convergence. Defaults to 1e-6.

  • atol (float, optional) – Absolute tolerance for convergence. Defaults to 1e-6.

  • wce_tol (float, optional) – Early stopping criterion based on the worst-case error. Iteration terminates when WCE falls below this threshold. Defaults to 0.0 (disabled).

  • maxiter (int, optional) – Maximum number of iterations. Defaults to 1000.

  • M_inv (Array, optional) – Preconditioner matrix \(M^{-1}\). Must be symmetric positive definite.

  • x0 (Array, optional) – Initial guess for the solution. If not provided, a zero vector is used.

Returns:

A 4-tuple containing:

  • x (Array): Final solution \(x_k\) to the system.

  • k (int): Number of iterations performed.

  • residuals (Array): Norms of residuals \(\|r_k\|\) at each iteration. Shape: (maxiter,).

  • wce (Array): Worst-case error estimates \(\sigma(w_k)\) at each iteration. Shape: (maxiter,).

Return type:

tuple

pcg_stein.pcg.pcg(A, b, *, rtol=1e-06, atol=1e-06, wce_tol=0.0, maxiter=1000, M_inv=None, x0=None)¶

Solves the linear system \(Ax = b\) using the Preconditioned Conjugate Gradient (PCG) method, and returns diagnostic information including the worst-case error in an RKHS.

This wrapper calls a JIT-compiled internal implementation and trims residual and error histories to the final iteration count. The worst-case error (WCE) provides a computable bound on the integration error when estimating expectations under a distribution using a weighted kernel quadrature rule.

Parameters:

  • A – Linear operator or matrix representing \(A\) (assumed symmetric positive semi-definite).

  • b (Array) – Right-hand side vector.

  • rtol (float, optional) – Relative convergence tolerance. Defaults to 1e-6.

  • atol (float, optional) – Absolute convergence tolerance. Defaults to 1e-6.

  • wce_tol (float, optional) – Tolerance for worst-case error early stopping. If WCE drops below this, iteration stops. Defaults to 0.0 (disabled).

  • maxiter (int, optional) – Maximum number of iterations. Defaults to 1000.

  • M_inv (Array, optional) – Preconditioner (approximate inverse of \(A\)). Defaults to None (no preconditioning).

  • x0 (Array, optional) – Initial guess for the solution. Defaults to zero if not provided.

Returns:

A 4-tuple containing:

  • x (Array): Final solution \(x_k\) to the system \(Ax = b\).

  • k (int): Number of iterations performed.

  • res_hist (Array): Residual norms \(\|r_k\|\) at each iteration. Shape: (k,).

  • wce_hist (Array): Worst-case error \(\sigma(\mathbf{w}_k)\) at each iteration. Shape: (k,).

Return type:

tuple

Notes

The worst-case error is defined by:

\[\sigma(\mathbf{w}_k) = \sup_{\|v\|_{\mathcal{H}(k_p)} \leq 1} \left| c_{N,k}(v) - \int v(\mathbf{x}) p(\mathbf{x}) \, \mathrm{d}\mathbf{x} \right| = \frac{ (\mathbf{w}_k^\top \mathbf{K}_p \mathbf{w}_k )^{1/2} }{ \mathbf{1}^\top \mathbf{w}_k },\]

where \(\mathbf{w}_k\) is the solution at iteration \(k\), and \(\mathbf{K}_p\) is the kernel matrix under a preconditioned kernel. This provides a proxy for integration error when the RKHS norm \(\|v\|_{\mathcal{H}(k_p)}\) is unknown.

pcg_stein.precon module¶

class pcg_stein.precon.BlockJacobi¶

Bases: Preconditioner

__call__(matrix, key=None, **kwargs)¶

Constructs a preconditioner using the Block Jacobi approximation, where the matrix is partitioned into diagonal blocks and each is inverted separately.

Parameters:

  • matrix (Array) – Symmetric positive semi-definite matrix of shape (n, n) to precondition.

  • key (Array, optional) – JAX PRNG key (ignored, included for API consistency).

  • block_size (int, keyword-only) – Size of the diagonal blocks used in the Jacobi approximation (required).

  • max_cond_number (float, optional) – Maximum condition number allowed for spectral pseudo-inverse. Defaults to 1e9.

  • kwargs (Any)

Returns:

Preconditioning matrix constructed via block-wise spectral pseudo-inversion.

Return type:

Array

name: str = 'Block Jacobi'¶
class pcg_stein.precon.FITC¶

Bases: Preconditioner

Fully–Independent Training Conditional (FITC) pre-conditioner.

__call__(matrix, key, **kwargs)¶

Constructs a preconditioner using the FITC (Fully Independent Training Conditional) approximation.

Parameters:

  • matrix (Array) – A symmetric positive semi-definite kernel matrix of shape (n, n).

  • key (Array) – JAX PRNG key used for selecting inducing indices if not explicitly provided.

  • m (int, keyword-only) – Number of inducing points (required).

  • nugget (float, keyword-only) – Diagonal jitter \(\sigma^2\) added to the kernel matrix (required).

  • indices (Array or list of int, optional) – Explicit array of inducing indices to use. If not provided, indices are selected using key.

  • max_cond_number (float, optional) – Maximum condition number threshold for applying a spectral pseudo-inverse.

Returns:

A matrix representing the FITC-based preconditioner.

Return type:

Array

name: str = 'FITC'¶
class pcg_stein.precon.Nystrom¶

Bases: Preconditioner

Random Index Nystrom preconditioner.

Approximates a symmetric matrix via a low-rank factorisation using random subsampling (by default).

__call__(matrix, key, return_mat_and_precon=False, **kwargs)¶

Construct the Nystrom preconditioner.

Parameters:

  • matrix (Array) – (n, n) symmetric matrix.

  • key (Array) – JAX random key.

  • return_mat_and_precon (bool) – bool (default False) Whether to return both the approximated matrix and its preconditioner (approximate inverse). If True, the function returns a tuple (preconditioner, matrix_approx); otherwise, only the preconditioner.

  • m – int, required. Number of columns/rows for Nystrom approximation.

  • max_cond_number – float, optional. Max condition number for pseudoinverse (default 1e9).

  • indices – array or None, optional. Explicit indices for Nystrom subset.

Return type:

Array

Returns:

(n, n) Nystrom preconditioner matrix.

name: str = 'Nystrom (no Woodbury)'¶
class pcg_stein.precon.NystromRandomDiagonalWoodbury¶

Bases: Preconditioner

Diagonally-weighted Random Index Nystrom preconditioner using the Woodbury formula.

Approximates (K + nugget * I)^{-1} by sampling columns of K with probability proportional to their diagonal values, and then applies the Woodbury identity for an approximate inverse.

This method differs from standard Nystrom by performing weighted (importance) column sampling.

__call__(matrix, key, **kwargs)¶

Construct the diagonal-weighted Nystrom preconditioner using the Woodbury formula.

Parameters:

  • matrix (Array) – Array (n, n) Symmetric matrix to be preconditioned.

  • key (Array) – Array Random key for reproducibility in sampling.

  • m – int, required in kwargs Number of columns/rows to sample for the Nystrom approximation.

  • max_cond_number – float, optional in kwargs Maximum allowed condition number for pseudoinverse (default 1e9).

  • nugget – float, required in kwargs Diagonal regularization parameter, added to the submatrix.

Returns:

Array (n, n)

Approximate inverse (K + nugget * I)^{-1} constructed via weighted Nystrom sampling and Woodbury identity.

Return type:

precon

name: str = 'Nystrom (diagonal sampling)'¶
class pcg_stein.precon.NystromRandomWoodbury¶

Bases: Preconditioner

Random Projection Nystrom preconditioner using the Woodbury formula.

Approximates (K + nugget * I)^{-1} by projecting the n x n matrix K into an m-dimensional random subspace, and applying the Woodbury identity to the resulting low-rank matrix.

This method differs from standard Nystrom by using a random Gaussian projection Ω (not random sampling of columns).

__call__(matrix, key, **kwargs)¶

Construct the random projection Nystrom preconditioner using the Woodbury formula.

Parameters:

  • matrix (Array) – Array (n, n) Symmetric matrix to be preconditioned.

  • key (Array) – Array Random key for reproducibility in random projection.

  • m – int, required in kwargs Target dimension for the projection (rank of the approximation).

  • max_cond_number – float, optional in kwargs Maximum allowed condition number for pseudoinverse (default 1e9).

  • nugget – float, required in kwargs Diagonal regularization parameter, added to the projected matrix.

Returns:

Array (n, n)

Approximate inverse (K + nugget * I)^{-1} constructed via random projection and the Woodbury identity.

Return type:

precon

name: str = 'Nystrom (random projection)'¶
class pcg_stein.precon.NystromWoodbury¶

Bases: Preconditioner

Random Index Nystrom preconditioner using the Woodbury formula.

Approximates (K + nugget * I)^{-1} using random column sampling and the Woodbury identity.

__call__(matrix, key, **kwargs)¶

Construct the Nystrom preconditioner using the Woodbury Inverse.

Parameters:

  • matrix (Array) – (n, n) symmetric matrix.

  • key (Array) – JAX random key.

  • m – int, required. Number of columns/rows for Nystrom approximation.

  • max_cond_number – float, optional. Max condition number for pseudoinverse (default 1e9).

  • indices – array or None, optional. Explicit indices for Nystrom subset.

  • nugget – float, required. Diagonal regularizer (added to K).

Returns:

(n, n) matrix.

Approximation to (K + nugget * I)^{-1} using the Nystrom-Woodbury formula.

Return type:

precon

name: str = 'Nystrom'¶
class pcg_stein.precon.Preconditioner¶

Bases: object

Base class for preconditioners.

n x n is the size of the original (square) matrix to be preconditioned. m x m is the size of the preconditioner or the number of columns in the low-rank approximation.

__call__(key, matrix, return_mat_and_precon=False, **kwargs)¶

Apply the preconditioner to the matrix.

Should be implemented in subclasses.

Parameters:

  • matrix (Array) – Array The matrix to precondition.

  • key (Array) – Array JAX random key, for any stochasticity required in the preconditioner.

  • return_mat_and_precon (bool) – bool (default False) Whether to return both the approximated matrix and its preconditioner (approximate inverse). If True, the function returns a tuple (preconditioner, matrix_approx); otherwise, only the preconditioner.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments for flexibility.

Return type:

Array

Returns:

Depends on subclass implementation.

name: str = 'base_precon'¶
spectral_pinv(matrix, max_cond_number=1000000000.0)¶

Computes the Moore-Penrose pseudoinverse of a matrix, with optional spectral clipping.

Parameters:

  • matrix (Array) – Array The matrix to invert (shape: [m, m]).

  • max_cond_number (float) – float, optional Maximum allowed condition number (largest/smallest singular value ratio). If provided, singular values smaller than s_max / max_cond_number are clipped for numerical stability. Default is 1e9.

Returns:

Array

The pseudoinverse of the input matrix (shape: [m, m]).

Return type:

matrix_inv

sub_matrix(key, matrix, m, indices=None)¶

Extracts submatrices for the Nystrom (or other) preconditioner.

Parameters:

  • matrix (Array) – Array Input matrix (shape: [n, n]).

  • key (Array) – Array JAX random key for sampling indices, if not provided.

  • m (int) – int Number of columns/rows to select (size of the submatrix).

  • indices (Optional[Array]) – Optional[Array], optional If given, use these indices directly (shape: [m,]). If None, sample indices randomly.

Returns:

Array

Submatrix for chosen indices (shape: [m, m]).

K_nm: Array

All rows, selected columns (shape: [n, m]).

K_mn: Array

All columns, selected rows (shape: [m, n]).

Return type:

K_mm

class pcg_stein.precon.RandomisedSVDWoodbury¶

Bases: Preconditioner

Computes a low-rank Woodbury inverse preconditioner using Randomized SVD with power iterations.

This approximates (K + nugget * I)^{-1} via a randomized SVD to get the dominant subspace, and then applies the Woodbury formula for efficient approximate inversion. Assumes K is symmetric or PSD.

__call__(matrix, key, **kwargs)¶

Construct a randomized SVD-based Woodbury preconditioner.

Parameters:

  • matrix (Array) – Array (n, n) Symmetric matrix to be preconditioned.

  • key (Array) – Array Random key for projection.

  • m – int, required in kwargs Target rank of the approximation.

  • nugget – float, required in kwargs Diagonal regularization parameter, added to K.

  • return_mat_and_precon – bool (default False) Whether to return both the approximated matrix and its preconditioner (approximate inverse). If True, the function returns a tuple (preconditioner, matrix_approx); otherwise, only the preconditioner.

  • n_iter – int, optional in kwargs Number of power iterations (default 2).

  • tau – float, optional in kwargs Tikhonov regularisation parameter for the inversion of eigenvalues (default 0.0).

  • max_cond_number – float, optional Maximum allowed condition number for pseudoinverse (default 1e14).

Returns:

Approximate inverse (K + nugget * I)^{-1} constructed via randomized SVD and the Woodbury identity.

Return type:

Array

name: str = 'Randomised SVD'¶
